question:
For some matrix $\mathbf{P} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix}$ with nonzero integer entries,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{P}^{-1} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{P}.\]Find the smallest possible value of $|a| + |b| + |c| + |d|.$
answer:
From the equation $\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{P}^{-1} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{P},$ we can multiply both sides by $\mathbf{P}$ on the left, to get
\[\mathbf{P} \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \mathbf{P}.\]Then
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix},\]so
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4a - b & 3a \\ 4c - d & 3c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ 3c & 3d \end{pmatrix}.\]Comparing entries, we get $4a - b = a,$ $3a = b,$ $4c - d = 3c,$ and $3c = 3d.$  These reduce to $b = 3a$ and $c = d,$ so
\[|a| + |b| + |c| + |d| = |a| + |3a| + |c| + |d| = 4|a| + 2|d|.\]Since $a,$ $b,$ $c,$ and $d$ are all nonzero integers, we minimize this by taking $a = \pm 1$ and $d = \pm 1,$ in which case $4|a| + 2|d| = \boxed{6}.$
agents_response:
Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}$ and $\mathbf{D} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.$ We know that
\[\mathbf{A} = \mathbf{P}^{-1} \mathbf{D} \mathbf{P}.\]This means that $\mathbf{A}\mathbf{P} = \mathbf{P}\mathbf{D},$ or
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4 & 3 \\ -1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 3 \end{pmatrix}.\]This expands as
\[\begin{pmatrix} 4a + 3c & 4b + 3d \\ -a & -b \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} a & 3b \\ c & 3d \end{pmatrix}.\]Matching the entries, we get $4a + 3c = a,$ $4b + 3d = 3b,$ and $-a = c$ and $-b = 3d.$ Then $a = -c$ and $b = -3d,$ so
\[\mathbf{P} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ -a & -3b \end{pmatrix}.\]Let $\det \mathbf{P} = x.$ Then $\det \mathbf{A} = \det \mathbf{P} \det \mathbf{D} \det \mathbf{P} = x \cdot 3x = 3x^2.$ Since $\det \mathbf{A} = -3,$ we have $3x^2 = -3,$ so $x = \pm 1.$

If $x = 1,$ then
\[\mathbf{P} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ -a & -3b \end{pmatrix}\]and $\mathbf{P}^{-1} = \frac{1}{-3b - a} \begin{pmatrix} -3b & -b \\ a & b \end{pmatrix},$ which makes the entries of $\mathbf{P}^{-1} \mathbf{D} \mathbf{P}$ ugly. However, if $x = -1,$ then
\[\mathbf{P} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ -a & 3b \end{pmatrix}\]and $\mathbf{P}^{-1} = \frac{1}{3b - a} \begin{pmatrix} 3b & -b \\ a & -b \end{pmatrix},$ which makes the entries of $\mathbf{P}^{-1} \mathbf{D} \mathbf{P}$ nice (the determinant of $\mathbf{P}$ does not even need to be calculated).

Therefore, $|a| + |b| + |c| + |d| = |-1| + |1| + |-1| + |3| = \boxed{6}.$
